body:
## Bevy version

`bevy_ecs` v0.16.1

## What you did

I was trying to store WGPU-related structs in an ECS resource:
```rust
#[derive(Resource)]
pub struct WgpuResource<
    #[expect(single_use_lifetimes, reason = "Deriving from Resource causes this.")]
    #[expect(redundant_lifetimes, reason = "Deriving from Resource causes this.")]
    'window> {
    pub surface: Surface<'window>,
    pub surface_config: SurfaceConfiguration,
    pub window: Arc<Window>,
    pub device: Device,
```

This compiles fine, but later I realized that I couldn't write `ResMut<WgpuResource>` to access the resource, because `ResMut<T>` requires that `T` is a `Resource`, which must be `'static`. If `Resource` must be `'static`, then why didn't it error out when I `derive`d it? I tried expanding the macro and found that this is what it expanded to:
```rust
impl<
    #[expect(single_use_lifetimes, reason = "Deriving from Resource causes this.")]
    #[expect(redundant_lifetimes, reason = "Deriving from Resource causes this.")] 'window,
> bevy_ecs::resource::Resource for WgpuResource<'window>
where
    Self: Send + Sync + 'static,
{
}
```

Because of the `where` clause, this `impl` is skipped for `WgpuResource` because it isn't `'static`. If I remove the `where` clause, then it correctly tells me that the lifetime bound isn't satisfied.

## What went wrong

I expected that the macro wouldn't add that `where` clause, so the user can see the problem sooner.
